head.title: Pyridinium-Functionalized Ionic Metal–Organic Frameworks Designed as Bifunctional Catalysts for CO2 Fixation into Cyclic Carbonates | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Pyridinium-Functionalized Ionic Metal–Organic Frameworks Designed as Bifunctional Catalysts for CO2 Fixation into Cyclic Carbonates

Ionic metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) offer a new platform to design and construct complete heterogeneous bifunctional catalytic systems for the chemical fixation of CO2 with epoxides. Herein, we developed a series of bifunctional pyridinium ionic MOF heterogeneous catalysts (66Pym-RXs and 67BPym-MeI) by the postsynthetic N-alkylation of noncoordinated pyridine sites in porous MOFs. The synergetic catalytic effect of acidic sites with nucleophilic anions in the ionic MOF significantly enhanced the catalytic activity toward the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates under cocatalyst-free and solvent-free mild conditions. The catalytic activity of ionic MOFs is easily tuned by the introduction of different alkyl groups into pyridinium cations and halide ions. The 66Pym-iPrI catalyst displayed the highest catalytic performance in terms of the turnover number value for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates. The proposed alternative method provides the means of developing functional N-heterocyclic groups for the new design of bifunctional ionic MOFs as potential heterogeneous catalysts for CO2 fixation applications.

div.p:
Ionic metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) offer a new platform to design and construct complete heterogeneous bifunctional catalytic systems for the chemical fixation of CO
2
with epoxides. Herein, we developed a series of bifunctional pyridinium ionic MOF heterogeneous catalysts (66Pym-RXs and 67BPym-MeI) by the postsynthetic N-alkylation of noncoordinated pyridine sites in porous MOFs. The synergetic catalytic effect of acidic sites with nucleophilic anions in the ionic MOF significantly enhanced the catalytic activity toward the cycloaddition of CO
2
with epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates under cocatalyst-free and solvent-free mild conditions. The catalytic activity of ionic MOFs is easily tuned by the introduction of different alkyl groups into pyridinium cations and halide ions. The 66Pym-
i
PrI catalyst displayed the highest catalytic performance in terms of the turnover number value for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates. The proposed alternative method provides the means of developing functional N-heterocyclic groups for the new design of bifunctional ionic MOFs as potential heterogeneous catalysts for CO
2
fixation applications.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are emerging as a promising class of synthetic porous crystalline materials consisting of a highly ordered covalent coordination network assembled by metal ions or clusters with multifunctional organic ligands. The unique combination of organic and inorganic moieties is predominantly arranged in a three-dimensional manner by repeating the coordination entities and facilitated the development of a new class of porous materials, which are potentially much more attractive than or complementary to the well-known zeolites, clays, or activated carbons.
(1−4)
In the last decade, research on MOFs was significantly enhanced and has attracted the attention of material chemists because of the outstanding applications in various fields.
(5−7)
MOFs have been considered as promising candidates for carbon capture, utilization, and storage because of the regular structures, high porosity, high surface area, high adsorption capacity, and easy functionalization of MOFs.
(8−10)
Owing to the existence of coordinatively unsaturated metal sites as acid centers, various MOFs have been successfully employed as heterogeneous catalysts for the chemical fixation of CO
2
with epoxides.
(11−15)
Most of the MOF catalysts are optimally effective with the addition of homogeneous nucleophilic cocatalysts such as organic salts or bases.
(15−18)
The separation of homogeneous cocatalysts from the reaction products is extremely complex and uneconomical for their industrial applications. To overcome this limitation, an attractive alternative strategy has recently demonstrated the utility of ionic MOFs as bifunctional catalysts by the installation of ionic components onto the MOF architectures, therefore, the existence of free counter anions in the pores of the framework.
(19−24)
The ionic MOFs provide a new pathway to obtain a complete heterogeneous catalyst platform for the production of commercially valuable cyclic carbonates and exclusively overcome the limitation of cocatalyst separation. Moreover, the synergetic effect of this one-component bifunctional ionic MOF catalyst exhibited an enhanced catalytic activity compared with the binary MOF catalytic systems (required of the external cocatalyst).

To date, several examples of heterogeneous bifunctional ionic MOF catalysts have been established.
(25−36)
Reported studies exposed that the use of quaternary ammonium-,
(25−27)
phosphonium-,
(28,29)
imidazolium-,
(26,30−35)
triazolium-,
(36)
or pyridinium
(37,38)
-functionalized ionic linkers can be successfully introduced as pendant groups on organic linkers (phenyl backbone ligands,
Figure
1
a). Furthermore, identifying the valid chemical tags with functional organic linkers is therefore of utmost significance for the development of new ionic MOF materials and that can be employed as versatile heterogeneous bifunctional catalysts for chemical fixation of CO
2
is highly desirable. With this information in hand, we desired to develop a new system in ionic MOFs via postsynthetic N-alkylation reactions of free noncoordinated Lewis basic sites of a core skeleton unit of organic linkers of MOFs (pyridine backbone ligands,
Figure
1
b).
(22−24)
The advantage of this strategy would avoid the additional synthetic steps to introduce required chemical tags (such as amino or imidazole) into the organic linkers. In addition, different functional groups can be introduced into the MOF structure for better tuning of the catalytic efficiency. Recently, zirconium MOFs (Zr-MOFs) have garnered significant research interest because of their large surface area, high porosity, and high thermal-chemical stability.
(39,40)

div.p:
Figure 1. Schematic representation of bifunctional ionic MOF catalysts for CO
2
fixation with epoxide; (a) previous and (b) this work.

div.div:
In this study, we selected free Lewis basic sites containing Zr-MOFs of UiO-66-Py (pyridine) and UiO-67-Bpy (bipyridine) for series of postsynthetic N-alkylation reactions.
(41,42)
Knowingly, postsynthetic metalation reactions are widely studied for UiO-67-Bpy because of the free coordination site of the 2,2′-bipyridine motif toward metal ions or metal complexes and the resultant functionalized MOF materials are applied to various applications.
(43)
Recently, a postsynthetic modification approach through N-alkylation of UiO-66-Py and UiO-67-Bpy has been described in the literature.
(41,44−46)
The postsynthetic N-alkylation of pyridine sites provides the neutral framework into ionic, which exhibits a bifunctional property. To the best of our knowledge, the direct functionalization of organic linkers as ionic MOFs via postsynthetic N-alkylation as bifunctional catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO
2
has not yet reported. Therefore, this present work designs the pyridinium ionic MOFs as bifunctional catalysts for the CO
2
fixation into five-membered cyclic carbonate.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The noncoordinated pyridine containing MOFs of UiO-66-Py (66Py) and UiO-67-BPy (67BPy) was synthesized by the solvothermal reaction of zirconium oxychloride (ZrOCl
2
·8H
2
O), acidic modulator (HCl solution and benzoic acid), and pyridine-containing dicarboxylic acid linkers [2,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (PyDC) and 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylate (BPyDC)] in
N
,
N
-dimethylformamide.
Figure
2
a demonstrates the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the synthesized 66Py and 67BPy showing that all the main diffraction patterns were similar, with conventional UiO-66 (∼7.5, 8.7, and 25.9°) and UiO-67 (∼5.8, 6.7, and 11.5°).
(47)
Then, we conducted the postsynthetic modification reactions of 66Py and 67BPy with N-alkylating agents under neat reaction conditions. This led the N-alkylation of the noncoordinated pyridine sites to produce ionic MOFs of 66Pym-RXs and 67BPym-MeI, respectively. The PXRD pattern indicated that the pyridinium-based ionic MOFs (66Pym-RXs and 67BPym-MeI; R = Me, Et,
n
Pr,
i
Pr and X = I, Br, Cl) are in good accordance with pristine MOFs (
Figures
2
a,
S3a and S4a
). As shown in
Figure S5
, the field emission scanning electron microscopic images exhibited that the morphology of pyridinium ionic MOFs (66Pym-MeI and 67BPym-MeI) with pristine MOFs was uniformed after N-alkylation.

div.p:
Figure 2. (a) PXRD patterns, (b) digested
1
H NMR spectra (HF/D
2
O/DMSO-
d
6
), (c,d) FT-IR spectra, and (e,f) Raman spectra of conventional UiO-66 (gray), conventional UiO-67 (black), 66Py (orange), 66Pym-MeI (pink), 67BPy (green), and 67BPym-MeI (blue) samples.

div.div:
To validate whether the N-alkylation reaction occurred in the 66Py and 67BPy frameworks, the N-alkylation was determined by the
1
H nuclear magnetic resonance (
1
H NMR) spectroscopic analysis of digested ionic MOF samples in NMR solvent mixtures.
Figure
2
b depicts the additional characteristic-shifted peaks of N-alkyl pyridinium ions that were compared with those of the pristine MOFs, which unambiguously confirmed the formation of N-alkyl-containing pyridinium cationic sites.
(41,45,46)
For example, when methyl iodide was employed as the N-alkylating agent, the 66Py pyridine linker was converted into
N
-methyl pyridinium at approximately 66%, based on the
1
H NMR ratio of PyDC and Pym-MeI linkers. On the other hand, the degree of N-methylation was relatively low (38%) for the 67BPy bipyridine linker, even though the modification was performed with a relatively long reaction time. However, the other N-alkylating agent reacting with 66Py exhibited an even lower reactivity by increasing the chain length and bulkiness of the alkyl groups. Similarly, the reactivity of alkyl halides was identified in the order of I > Br > Cl for identical alkyl groups (
Figures S3b and S4b
).
(48)

Additionally, the successful N-alkylation of pyridine sites was further established by the Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopic analysis of ionic MOFs. The FT-IR spectra of all of the 66Pym-RXs exhibit an additional characteristic of aliphatic C–H vibrational bands in the range between 1300 and 1100 cm
–1
. The pyridinium carboxylate ring vibration band at ∼1620 cm
–1
shifted when compared with that of the pyridine ring vibration band at ∼1595 cm
–1
for 66Py. Similarly, the 67BPym-MeI demonstrates additional methyl peaks at 1291 and 1199 cm
–1
, whereas the pyridinium carboxylate ring vibration band occurred at ∼1640 cm
–1
(
Figures
2
c,d,
S3c, and S4c
).
(49)
The Raman spectra also reveal the new pyridinium ring vibration band for each modified samples (
Figure
2
e,f). These combined results clearly indicate that the pyridinium-containing MOFs were successfully synthesized and the crystalline structure of the functionalized ionic MOFs was unchanged and remained intact during the postsynthetic modification process.

Moreover, the existence of cationic pyridinium species and counter halide anions was also examined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of ionic MOF samples (
Figure
3
).
Figure
3
a shows that the XPS survey analysis of 66Pym-MeI and 67BPy-MeI exhibited all the main element peaks derived from the inorganic nodes and linker components. Additionally, the new distinct peaks associated with I
3d
appeared in the XPS spectrum compared with the pristine MOFs (66Py and 66BPy). Particularly, the high-resolution XPS spectrum of N
1s
exhibited a characteristic peak at 402 eV that confirmed the successful formation of the positively charged N-pyridinium cations, which were obtained by the quaternization of the pyridine site with an alkylating agent, whereas the unreacted free pyridine linkers produced a peak at ∼399 eV and complement the pristine MOF peaks (
Figure
3
b). In addition,
Figure
3
c shows that the XPS spectra of the I
3d
region exhibited two peaks at around 618 and 629 eV, corresponding to I 3d
5/2
and I 3d
3/2
, respectively. This indicates the existence of negatively charged iodide anions. Similarly, the other ionic MOFs containing the bromide and chloride counter anions were confirmed by the corresponding ionic states at 68 and 198 eV for bromide and chloride ions, respectively (
Figures S6 and S7
). All these results implies that the pyridinium cations and halide anions can be successfully introduced to the 66Py and 67BPy frameworks via the postsynthetic N-alkylation method and provided ionicity to the MOF catalysts.
(50)

div.p: Figure 3. (a) Survey analysis, (b) nitrogen 1s, and (c) iodine 3p XPS spectra of 66Py (orange), 66Pym-MeI (pink), 67BPy (green), and 67BPym-MeI (blue) samples.

div.div:
After, the coexistence of both inorganic acidic Zr
6
(μ
3
–O)
4
(μ
3
–OH)
4
sites and nucleophilic counter ions on the MOF structures, we then investigated the catalytic performance of our designed bifunctional MOF catalysts toward the chemical fixation of CO
2
with epoxide to produce cyclic carbonates. Initially, we selected butylene oxide (BO) as a trial substrate to explore the CO
2
fixation reaction under cocatalyst-free and solvent-free conditions using BO (20 mmol), MOF catalysts (50 mg), and CO
2
(5 bar) at 100 °C for 24 h (
Table
1
). Under the reaction conditions, 66Pym-MeI and 67BPym-MeI catalysts successfully promoted the cycloaddition of BO to CO
2
, thus yielding butylene carbonate (BC) with yields of 87.7 and 75.2%, respectively (
Table
1
, entries 1 and 2). To validate the bifunctionality of the ionic MOF catalyst, the nonfunctionalized pristine MOFs (66Py and 67BPy) were examined as catalysts under the same conditions, which were of inefficient catalytic performance for the cyclic carbonate synthesis (
Table
1
, entries 3 and 4). This result highlights the pivotal role of the nucleophilic iodide ion toward the chemical fixation of CO
2
with epoxide. On the other hand, the ionic liquid
N
-methyl pyridinium iodide [(MePym)
+
(I)
−
] was investigated as a single-component catalyst for the cycloaddition reaction between BO and CO
2
, which afforded a lower yield of 67.6% of BC (
Table
1
, entry 5). The result indicates the importance of acidic sites in the MOF structure of the catalyst for the effective activation of epoxide toward the ring-opening step of the catalytic process.
(51−53)
Next, we demonstrated the effect of the nucleophilicity of counter ions on MOF catalysts. It was observed that 66Pym-MeOTs and 67BPym-MeOTs were unable to promote the CO
2
fixation reaction with epoxide because of the relatively poor nucleophilicity of tosylate ions compared with iodide ions (
Table
1
, entries 6 and 7). Besides the effect of acidic centers, the nucleophilicity of the pyridinium counter ion also plays a significant role in the catalytic activity. Therefore, the overall experimental results indicated that the high catalytic performance of ionic bifunctional MOF catalysts could be achieved by the combination of both the acidic sites and the nucleophilicity of counter ions. These active sites work synergistically to enhance the chemical fixation of CO
2
with epoxide.

Table 1. Synthesis of Cyclic Carbonates with BO Using Various Types of Catalysts
a

div.p:
Reaction conditions: BO (20 mmol), catalyst (50 mg), CO
2
pressure (5 bar), reaction temperature (100 °C), and reaction time (24 h).

The cyclic carbonate yields were determined by
1
H NMR.

Turnover number (TON) = moles of the product/mole of iodide with the number of pyridinium in MOFs determined by
1
H NMR.
0.2 mmol 1-methylpyridinium iodide (44.2 mg) was used as a catalyst.

div.div:
Subsequently, the effect of various reaction parameters, such as temperature, pressure, time, and the amount of catalyst on the cycloaddition of CO
2
with BO was investigated (see
Section S8
). As shown in
Tables S3 and S4
, when the reaction temperature was increased from 60 to 100 °C, the yield of BC was remarkably enhanced. Interestingly, the reaction at ambient CO
2
pressure resulted in a considerable transformation into BC. As the reaction time decreased, the yield of BC also dramatically decreased. A sharp decline in the BC yield was observed when the catalyst loading further decreased from 50 to 12.5 mg. In particular, the tendency of reactions greatly differed with the amount of catalysts compared with other variables, which is expected because the effect was influenced by the frameworks for the mass transfer of reactants to contact the catalytic sites in the MOF catalysts.
(54)

Generally, the heterogeneous MOF catalysts are easily separated from the reaction systems and are also reusable for successive runs. We conducted experiments to further validate the reusability of the ionic MOFs in the cycloaddition of CO
2
with BO (see
Section S9
). Unfortunately, the pyridinium-based ionic MOFs gradually decreased the catalytic activity and also did not demonstrate good reusability in the CO
2
cycloaddition reaction. During the reaction process, the ionic MOF slowly decomposed and tended to collapse, as indicated by the PXRD patterns, Ar adsorption/desorption isotherms, and digested
1
H NMR of the reused 66Pym-MeI catalyst (
Figure S17
). It may be assumed that the structure of the ionic MOF was not well-maintained because of the weakened carboxylate coordination with zirconium clusters affected by the positive charge resulting from the formation of pyridinium.
(24,55)
To confirm a possible homogeneously action of leached active sites of 66Pym-MeI into the reaction mixture while the reaction, a hot catalyst filtration test was performed after 24 h of reaction at 80 °C. The further yield of BC in the filtrate is slightly increased by 65.4 to 67.1% after more than 24 h of reaction. These results demonstrate that the 66Pym-MeI is due to the collapsed structure; in addition, the leached active sites into the reaction mixture detected a small amount of Zr (78.6 ppm) and I
–
(126.7 ppm) (
Table S7
).

Next, we studied the suitability of various N-alkylated bifunctional ionic MOF catalysts toward improving the catalytic cycloaddition of CO
2
. To validate this, we synthesized a series of ionic MOF catalysts through the N-alkylation reaction of 66Py with different alkyl halides via postfunctionalization. The catalytic efficiency of synthesized ionic MOF catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO
2
with BO was examined under optimized conditions and the results are shown in
Table
2
. The alkyl chain influences the catalytic cycloaddition effectively with an increase in the yield of BC (entries 1, 2, and 4). We trust that an improved performance of the catalyst exerted by the effect of the pyridinium cation on this reaction was due to the result of structural differences among the pyridinium cations, which possibly affect the efficiency of iodide anions directly. An improved catalytic effect was displayed by 66Pym-
n
PrI because of the bulkiness of the substituent, which forced the iodide ion away from the pyridinium cations, thus resulting in an enhanced nucleophilicity of the anion and consequently, an increase in the reactivity of the catalyst. The size of the different alkyl chains of the pyridinium cation increases in the following order [Pym-Me]
+
< [Pym-Et]
+
< [Pym-
n
Pr]
+
, and in the same manner, the cyclic carbonate formation also increases with the increase in cation size. We further investigated the nucleophilicity of the halide ions on the MOF catalysts with a similar cation size (
Table
2
).
(26,56)
Among the examined MOF catalysts, the catalytic performance firmly depended on the nucleophilicity of counter anions and the optimum yield was obtained using iodide ion-containing MOFs in the cycloaddition of BO to BC (entries 2–6). This large difference in catalytic property replicates the nucleophilicity and leaving tendency of halide ions under solvent-free cycloaddition conditions. Therefore, the order of the activity of the halide ions is I > Br > Cl.
(57)
Based on these results, we conclude that the nucleophilicity of anions extremely influenced the reaction rate along with the structure (size) of the pyridinium cations. Additionally, we prepared the 66Pym-
i
PrI catalyst through the N-alkylation of 66Py with isopropyl iodide (
i
PrI). Interestingly, the catalytic activity was more efficient and demonstrated a significant difference in CO
2
cycloaddition compared with that of other linear alkyl iodide MOFs. This result was unexpected when considering variables that potentially enhance the catalytic activity. After careful evaluation of N-alkylation reaction results, we determined the relationship between the catalytic transformation and the degree of N-alkylation. As the degree of N-alkylation decreased, the turnover number (TON) value for the cyclic carbonate synthesis increased from 200.5 to 234.1 (entries 1, 2, and 4). For 66Pym-
i
PrI, the degree of alkylation was extremely low compared with that of other linear alkyl iodide-substituted MOFs because of the steric effect of isopropyl iodide. The MOF exhibited high reactivity because the sterically crowded pyridinium cation forces the iodide ion to be more nucleophilic and resulted in the highest TON value of 665.1 (entry 7). Also, the free void is an additional advantage that improves the mass transport of both reactants and products compared with other N-alkylated ionic MOFs.
(16,54,58)

Table 2. Synthesis of Cyclic Carbonates with BO and Carbon Dioxide Using Various Ionic MOFs
a

div.p:
Reaction conditions: BO (20 mmol), catalyst (50 mg), CO
2
pressure (5 bar), reaction temperature (100 °C), and reaction time (24 h).

The cyclic carbonate yields were determined by
1
H NMR.

Turnover number (TON) = moles of the product/mole of halide ions with the number of pyridinium in MOFs determined by
1
H NMR.

div.div:
To explore the scope of the 66Pym-MeI and 67BPym-MeI bifunctional catalysts, the cycloaddition of CO
2
with different epoxides was studied for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates (
Table
3
). Generally, the high catalytic yield was observed for small epoxides, such as propylene oxide, epichlorohydrin (ECH), and epibromohydrin (EBH), to produce the corresponding cyclic carbonates with high TON values under the cocatalyst-free and solvent-free conditions. Noticeably, the catalytic activity difference between MOF catalysts (66Pym-MeI and 67BPym-MeI) was identified for the epoxides of allyl glycidyl ether and styrene oxide in the cycloaddition of CO
2
. A possible reason for the reduction in the catalytic performance of MOF catalysts can be recognized by the restriction of epoxide diffusion into the active site of catalysts.
(16,58)

Table 3. Synthesis of Various Cyclic Carbonates with Different Epoxides and Conditions Using 66Pym-MeI and 67BPym-MeI
a

div.p:
Reaction conditions: epoxide (20 mmol), catalyst (50 mg), CO
2
pressure (5 bar), reaction temperature (100 °C), and reaction time (24 h).
Entries 1–6a used 66Pym-MeI as a catalyst and entries 1–6b used 67BPym-MeI as a catalyst.

The cyclic carbonate yields were determined by
1
H NMR.

Turnover number (TON) = moles of the product/mole of iodide with the number of pyridinium in MOFs determined by
1
H NMR.

div.div:
To understand this result, we calculated changes in the surface area and pore size distribution of all the synthesized MOFs (
Figure
4
). The argon adsorption isotherms of N-functionalized catalysts revealed a significant decrease in the amount of adsorbed gas per weight compared with the pristine 66Py and 67BPy. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area of pristine 66py and 67BPy was calculated as 1318 and 1537 m
2
/g, respectively. After post-N-methylation, the surface area of 66Pym-MeI and 67BPym-MeI decreased to 732 and 1073 m
2
/g, respectively. Because of this decreased surface area, the introduced methyl groups and iodide anions inevitably occupy the pores of the framework. However, the result indicated that the ionic MOFs still exhibited a high surface area, which assisted the free diffusion of the reactants and products during the cycloaddition of CO
2
. Moreover, the nonlocalized density functional theory (NLDFT) revealed that the pore size of functionalized 66Pym-MeI and 67BPym-MeI is comparable to distributions of the inner pore width against the pristine MOFs. These functionalized
N
-methyl pyridinium groups do not have a significant effect on the inner cages of ionic MOFs. Regardless of the high surface area and pore size, the mass diffusion of epoxides toward the catalytic sites can be greatly affected by other factors, that is may be, the size of the epoxide reactants and the size of the window of the ionic MOFs (see
Section S11
). To investigate this, the triangular window of nonfunctionalized 66Py has a diameter of 6.3 AÅ, which considers the critical diameters and width of reactants. This size can account for the most valid window diameter, which provides a size sufficient for allyl glycidyl ether to pass through the window within MOFs. Based on the progress of the methylation of 66Py, the size of the window can be gradually decreased. Therefore, the diffusion of allyl glycidyl ether and styrene oxide does not easily reach into the inner cages of 66Pym-MeI where most of the catalytic sites are present. Nevertheless, the window size of 67BPym-MeI can be quite sufficient and is considered to be of low steric effect, which allows the allyl glycidyl ether and styrene oxide to readily pass through the window to reach the active site of the MOF catalyst. This illustrates the difference in catalytic activity of the two catalysts for the catalytic cycloaddition of CO
2
with allyl glycidyl ether and styrene oxide and also highlights the role of window size on the design of MOF catalysts.
(59,60)

div.p: Figure 4. (a,b) Ar adsorption/desorption isotherms and (c,d) NLDFT pore size distributions of 66Py (orange), 66Pym-MeI (pink), 67BPy (green), and 67BPym-MeI (blue) samples.

div.div:
Based on our experimental results and preceding reports, a plausible cooperative mechanism was proposed for the pyridinium-functionalized ionic MOF catalysts. Initially, the cycloaddition of CO
2
with epoxide involves the activation coordination of the epoxide with an acidic sites lead to polarize the C–O bond of the epoxide, followed by the ring-opening step of the nucleophilic iodide ion on the less-hindered side of the epoxide, thus resulting in a metal-alkoxide intermediate. Subsequently, the alkoxide anion reacts with the CO
2
leading to a metal carbonate species. Finally, it undergoes an intramolecular ring-closing step to obtain cyclic carbonate with simultaneous regeneration bifunctional catalysts for the next catalytic cycle (
Figure
5
).

div.p:
Figure 5. Proposed mechanism for the cycloaddition of CO
2
with epoxides using ionic MOF catalysts.

div.div:
In addition, we questioned the high catalytic efficiency of these ionic MOF catalysts against epihalohydrins compared with other epoxides, especially BO. All three epoxides are relatively similar in size but showed different reactivities. We assume that this catalytic behavior may be due to the self N-alkylation reaction between the ionic MOF with epihalohydrins (see
Section S12
). This strategy was a unique property of ionic MOF catalysts compared with other types of MOF catalysts toward the CO
2
fixation reaction with epoxides.
(31,61)
To address this high catalytic effect, we performed the cycloaddition of CO
2
with epihalohydrins in the presence of nonfunctionalized MOFs as a catalyst under the same reaction conditions (
Table
4
). In the case of UiO-66 and UiO-67 MOFs, there was not a significant effect on the CO
2
fixation reaction with epihalohydrins to form cyclic carbonates, which suggests the absence of the pyridine moiety in the MOF structures. However, the pyridine-containing MOFs (66Py and 67BPy) undergo efficient CO
2
fixation reactions with epihalohydrins, and the EBH exhibits a higher yield than the ECH to produce the corresponding cyclic carbonates. This difference in reactivity may be ascribed to the variation in the nucleophilicity of the halide ions during the cycloaddition of CO
2
. In order to validate this self N-alkylation reaction, we conducted a reaction between the pyridine-containing MOFs (66Py and 67BPy) and ECH. The formation of the pyridinium ion was confirmed by FT-IR, digested
1
H NMR, and PXRD of 66Pym-ECH and 67BPym-ECH (
Figure S24
). Furthermore, the elemental analysis was carried out for the isolated catalysts after the cycloaddition of CO
2
with epihalohydrins and the results are summarized in
Table S8
. The experimental results revealed that epihalohydrin itself can act as a self N-alkylation agent to react with the noncoordinated pyridine site of MOFs. This further enhanced the catalytic efficiency of the ionic MOF catalysts toward epihalohydrins in the cycloaddition reaction of CO
2
and a possible mechanism was also proposed (
Figure S25
).

Table 4. Synthesis of Various Cyclic Carbonates with ECH and EBH Using Various MOFs
a

div.p:
Reaction conditions: epoxide (20 mmol), catalyst (50 mg), CO
2
pressure (5 bar), reaction temperature (100 °C), and reaction time (24 h).

The cyclic carbonate yields were determined by
1
H NMR.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In summary, we successfully designed a new strategy to synthesize porous ionic Zr-MOFs containing inorganic acidic sites, and free halogen anions are constructed by the postsynthetic modification of the noncoordinated pyridine sites of core organic linkers with N-alkylating agents. The pyridinium-functionalized ionic MOFs were designed as efficient bifunctional catalysts for cycloaddition of CO
2
with epoxides under cocatalyst-free and solvent-free mild conditions. The enhanced catalytic activity of ionic MOFs compared with that of the pristine MOFs was attributed to the synergetic effect of acidic sites and nucleophilic iodide ions in this framework. In addition, we investigated the effect of the alkyl groups of functionalized pyridinium cations and different counter anions toward the catalytic activity of bifunctional MOF catalysts. Among a series of ionic MOFs, the 66Pym-
i
PrI catalyst displayed a high catalytic performance in terms of the TON value for the cyclic carbonate synthesis. Finally, the bifunctional MOF catalysts, 66Pym-MeI and 67BPym-MeI, were used to study the scope of cycloaddition reactions with various epoxides. The difference in catalytic activity shows that the window size of an MOF is important for CO
2
cycloaddition catalysts for the diffusion of substrates. Further progress of this work is currently underway to synthesize a more robust framework with good stability, high catalytic activity, and reusability of MOF catalysts. Overall, this effort establishes an alternative approach for the introduction of functional ionic groups into MOF structures instead of a strategy dependent on pendant group functionalization in the design of bifunctional ionic MOF catalysts. Furthermore, this study is expected to encourage other researchers in designing new pyridinium-based MOF materials for applications in catalysis.

A review. This crit. review will be of interest to the experts in porous solids (including catalysis), but also solid state chemists and physicists. It presents the state-of-the-art on hybrid porous solids, their advantages, their new routes of synthesis, the structural concepts useful for their 'design', aiming at reaching very large pores. Their dynamic properties and the possibility of predicting their structure are described. The large tunability of the pore size leads to unprecedented properties and applications. They concern adsorption of species, storage and delivery and the phys. properties of the dense phases. (323 refs.).

During the past decade, interest has grown tremendously in the design and synthesis of cryst. materials constructed from mol. clusters linked by extended groups of atoms. Most notable are metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), in which polyat. inorg. metal-contg. clusters are joined by polytopic linkers. (Although these materials are sometimes referred to as coordination polymers, we prefer to differentiate them, because MOFs are based on strong linkages that yield robust frameworks.) The realization that MOFs could be designed and synthesized in a rational way from mol. building blocks led to the emergence of a discipline that we call reticular chem.MOFs can be represented as a special kind of graph called a periodic net. Such descriptions date back to the earliest crystallog. studies but have become much more common recently because thousands of new structures and hundreds of underlying nets have been reported. In the simplest cases (e.g., the structure of diamond), the atoms in the crystal become the vertices of the net, and bonds are the links (edges) that connect them. In the case of MOFs, polyat. groups act as the vertices and edges of the net.Because of the explosive growth in this area, a need has arisen for a universal system of nomenclature, classification, identification, and retrieval of these topol. structures. We have developed a system of symbols for the identification of three periodic nets of interest, and this system is now in wide use. In this Account, we explain the underlying methodol. of assigning symbols and describe the Reticular Chem. Structure Resource (RCSR), in which about 1600 such nets are collected and illustrated in a database that can be searched by symbol, name, keywords, and attributes. The resource also contains searchable data for polyhedra and layers.The database entries come from systematic enumerations or from known chem. compds. or both. In the latter case, refs. to occurrences are provided. We describe some crystallog., topol., and other attributes of nets and explain how they are reported in the database. We also describe how the database can be used as a tool for the design and structural anal. of new materials. Assocd. with each net is a natural tiling, which is a natural partition of space into space-filling tiles. The database allows export of data that can be used to analyze and illustrate such tilings.

Postsynthetic Tuning of Metal-Organic Frameworks for Targeted Applications
Islamoglu, Timur; Goswami, Subhadip; Li, Zhanyong; Howarth, Ashlee J.; Farha, Omar K.; Hupp, Joseph T.

A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are periodic, hybrid, atomically well-defined porous materials that typically form by self-assembly and consist of inorg. nodes (metal ions or clusters) and multitopic org. linkers. MOFs as a whole offer many intriguing properties, including ultrahigh porosity, tunable chem. functionality, and low d. These properties point to numerous potential applications, including gas storage, chem. sepns., catalysis, light harvesting, and chem. sensing, to name a few. Reticular chem., or the linking of mol. building blocks into predetd. network structures, was employed to synthesize thousands of MOFs. Given the vast library of candidate nodes and linkers, the no. of potentially synthetically accessible MOFs is enormous. Nevertheless, a powerful complementary approach to obtain specific structures with desired chem. functionality is to modify known MOFs after synthesis. This approach is particularly useful when incorporation of particular chem. functionalities via direct synthesis is challenging or impossible. The challenges may stem from limited stability or soly. of precursors, unwanted secondary reactivity of precursors, or incompatibility of functional groups with the conditions needed for direct synthesis. MOFs can be postsynthetically modified by replacing the metal nodes and/or org. linkers or via functionalization of the metal nodes and/or org. linkers. Here, the authors describe some of their efforts toward the development and application of postsynthetic strategies for imparting desired chem. functionalities in MOFs of known topol. The techniques include methods for functionalizing MOF nodes, i.e., solvent-assisted ligand incorporation (SALI) and at. layer deposition in MOFs (AIM) as well as a method to replace structural linkers, termed solvent-assisted linker exchange (SALE), also known as postsynthetic exchange (PSE). For each functionalization strategy, the authors first describe its chem. basis along with the requirements for its successful implementation. The authors then present a small no. of examples, with an emphasis on those that (a) convey the underlying concepts and/or (b) lead to functional structures (e.g., catalysts) that would be difficult or impossible to access via direct routes. The examples, however, are only illustrative, and a significant body of work exists from both the authors' lab and others, esp. for the SALE/PSE strategy. The authors refer readers to the papers cited and to the refs. therein. More exciting, in the authors' view, will be new examples and new applications of the functionalization strategies, esp. applications made possible by creatively combining the strategies. Under-explored (again, in the authors' view) are implementations that impart elec. cond., enable increasingly selective chem. sensing, or facilitate cascade catalysis. It will be interesting to see where these strategies and others take this compelling field over the next few years.

Multi-component hierarchically porous materials are an emerging class of materials with tailored compns., tunable distribution and sophisticated applications. An increasing demand for multifunctionalities and hierarchical structures has resulted in extensive studies on multi-component hierarchical metal-org. frameworks and other open framework compds. This review article focuses on recent advances in multi-component and hierarchical framework materials, covering the design and synthetic strategies of these architectures, their characterization, and the latest applications. Multivariate MOFs prepd. under various synthetic conditions (one-pot or post-synthetic) and their building block distributions are introduced and summarized. This is followed by a short review of characterization techniques including solid-state NMR and photothermal induced resonance, and their potential applications in gas storage, sepn., heterogeneous catalysis, guest delivery, and luminescence. Furthermore, guided by the same design principles, the synthesis and applications of multi-component hierarchical covalent-org. frameworks, metal-org. cages and porous org. cages are introduced and discussed. Together, this review is expected to provide a library of multi-component hierarchically porous compds., which could also guide the state-of-the-art design and discovery of future porous materials with unprecedented tunability, synergism and precision.

In recent years, metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) have been regarded as one of the most important classes of materials. The combination of various metal clusters and ligands, arranged in a vast array of geometries has led to an ever-expanding MOF family. Each year, new and novel MOF structures are discovered. The structural diversity present in MOFs has significantly expanded the application of these new materials. MOFs show great potential for a variety of applications, including but not limited to: gas storage and sepn., catalysis, biomedicine delivery, and chem. sensing. This review intends to offer a short summary of some of the most important topics and recent development in MOFs. The scope of this review shall cover the fundamental aspects concerning the design and synthesis of MOFs and range to the practical applications regarding their stability and deriv. structures. Emerging trends of MOF development will also be discussed. These trends shall include multicomponent MOFs, defect development in MOFs, and MOF composites. The ever important structure-property-application relationship for MOFs will also be investigated. Overall, this review provides insight into both existing structures and emerging aspects of MOFs.

The carbon dioxide challenge is one of the most pressing problems facing our planet. Each stage in the carbon cycle - capture, regeneration and conversion - has its own materials requirements. Recent work on metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) demonstrated the potential and effectiveness of these materials in addressing this challenge. In this Review, we identify the specific structural and chem. properties of MOFs that have led to the highest capture capacities, the most efficient sepns. and regeneration processes, and the most effective catalytic conversions. The interior of MOFs can be designed to have coordinatively unsatd. metal sites, specific heteroatoms, covalent functionalization, other building unit interactions, hydrophobicity, porosity, defects and embedded nanoscale metal catalysts with a level of precision that is crucial for the development of higher-performance MOFs. To realize a total soln., it is necessary to use the precision of MOF chem. to build more complex materials to address selectivity, capacity and conversion together in one material.

A review. Rapidly increasing atm. CO2 concns. threaten human society, the natural environment, and the synergy between the two. In order to ameliorate the CO2 problem, carbon capture and conversion techniques have been proposed. Metal-org. framework (MOF)-based materials, a relatively new class of porous materials with unique structural features, high surface areas, chem. tunability and stability, have been extensively studied with respect to their applicability to such techniques. Recently, it has become apparent that the CO2 capture capabilities of MOF-based materials significantly boost their potential toward CO2 conversion. Furthermore, MOF-based materials' well-defined structures greatly facilitate the understanding of structure-property relationships and their roles in CO2 capture and conversion. In this review, we provide a comprehensive account of significant progress in the design and synthesis of MOF-based materials, including MOFs, MOF composites and MOF derivs., and their application to carbon capture and conversion. Special emphases on the relationships between CO2 capture capacities of MOF-based materials and their catalytic CO2 conversion performances are discussed.

Carbon capture and storage (CCS): the way forward
Bui, Mai; Adjiman, Claire S.; Bardow, Andre; Anthony, Edward J.; Boston, Andy; Brown, Solomon; Fennell, Paul S.; Fuss, Sabine; Galindo, Amparo; Hackett, Leigh A.; Hallett, Jason P.; Herzog, Howard J.; Jackson, George; Kemper, Jasmin; Krevor, Samuel; Maitland, Geoffrey C.; Matuszewski, Michael; Metcalfe, Ian S.; Petit, Camille; Puxty, Graeme; Reimer, Jeffrey; Reiner, David M.; Rubin, Edward S.; Scott, Stuart A.; Shah, Nilay; Smit, Berend; Trusler, J. Carbon capture and storage (CCS) is broadly recognized as having the potential to play a key role in meeting climate change targets, delivering low carbon heat and power, decarbonising industry and, more recently, its ability to facilitate the net removal of CO2 from the atm. However, despite this broad consensus and its tech. maturity, CCS has not yet been deployed on a scale commensurate with the ambitions articulated a decade ago. Thus, in this paper we review the current state-of-the-art of CO2 capture, transport, utilization and storage from a multi-scale perspective, moving from the global to mol. scales. In light of the COP21 commitments to limit warming to less than 2 °C, we extend the remit of this study to include the key neg. emissions technologies (NETs) of bioenergy with CCS (BECCS), and direct air capture (DAC). Cognisant of the non-tech. barriers to deploying CCS, we reflect on recent experience from the UK's CCS commercialisation program and consider the com. and political barriers to the large-scale deployment of CCS. In all areas, we focus on identifying and clearly articulating the key research challenges that could usefully be addressed in the coming decade.

A review. The capture and chem. fixation of carbon dioxide (CO2) into cyclic carbonates is considered to be a promising way to alleviate CO2 concerns and produce fine chems. This process can be effectively promoted by various kinds of newly developed porous heterogeneous catalysts with Lewis acidic and nucleophilic sites. These porous catalytic materials include metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), covalent-org. frameworks (COFs), nanoporous ionic org. networks (NIONs) and amorphous porous org. polymers. In this review, we have briefly classified these materials based on their different structural features and compns. The syntheses and catalytic performances of these porous heterogeneous catalysts are described from the perspective of catalyst design. This review will guide material scientists attempting to design more efficient porous catalysts for CO2 capture and conversions.

A review. The redn. of the representative greenhouse gas, carbon dioxide (CO2), is significantly an important theme for the current research in the modern chem. world. For the last two decades, the development of new metal-org. framework (MOF) systems with highly selective capture of CO2, in the presence of other competing gaseous mols., has flourished to capture or sep. CO2 for environmental protection. Nonetheless, the ultimate resoln. to lessen the atm. CO2 concn. may be in the chem. or electrochem. conversion of CO2 to other compds. In this context, the catalytic cycloaddn. reaction of CO2 into org. epoxides to produce cyclic carbonates is a more attractive method. MOFs are being proven as efficient heterogeneous catalytic systems for this important reaction. In this review, we collected very recent progress in MOF-based catalytic systems, fully operable under very mild reaction conditions (room temp. and 1 atm CO2).

Metal org. framework (MOF) structures of UIO-66, UIO-66-NH2, Mg-MOF-74, MIL-101, CuBTC, ZIF-8, IRMOF-3, and MOF-5 having different acid/base properties were prepd. and tested for their catalytic activity in the CO2 cycloaddn. to styrene epoxide using a high-pressure batch reactor. The high crystallinity and excellent textural properties of the prepd. MOF materials were confirmed by x-ray diffraction and the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K. Their catalytic cycloaddn. activities were found to be well correlated with the Lewis acid/base distributions of the materials examd. by NH3- and CO2-TPD, resp., such that the concurrent presence of Lewis acid and base sites were desirable for high catalytic activity. For a given catalyst wt., UIO-66-NH2 showed the best catalytic performance among the MOF samples tested with close to 100% selectivity to carbonate in chlorobenzene under relatively mild reaction conditions (2.0 MPa, 373 K). UIO-66-NH2 could be reused 3 times without losing catalytic activity in a truly heterogeneous mode without structural deterioration, and it also exhibited excellent cycloaddn. activities for different epoxide substrates as well.

Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) have shown great promise as efficient CO2 adsorbents, as well as an emerging class of heterogeneous catalysts for conversion of CO2 to other useful chems. In this work, we synthesized and characterized two isostructural hafnium-based MOFs, denoted as Hf-VPI-100 (Cu) and Hf-VPI-100 (Ni). Both frameworks demonstrated high catalytic efficiency for cycloaddn. of CO2 to epoxides under ambient pressure. In situ PXRD, QCM and DRIFTs have been used to probe the interaction between the guest mols. (CO2/epoxide) and Hf-VPI-100. The crystal structures of these frameworks were preserved during the exposure to CO2 atmosphere up to 20 bar. The epoxide uptake per unit cell of VPI-100 and diffusion coeffs. have been calcd. by QCM anal. Comparison of catalytic efficiency between Hf-VPI-100 and the previously reported Zr-based VPI-100, aided by electronic structure calcns. revealed that the open metal centers in the metallocyclam act as the primary Lewis acid sites to facilitate the catalytic conversion of CO2.

A highly porous metal-org. framework (MOF) incorporating both exposed metal sites and nitrogen-rich triazole groups was successfully constructed via solvothermal assembly of a clicked octcarboxylate ligand and Cu(II) ions, which presents a high affinity toward CO2 mols. clearly verified by gas adsorption and Raman spectral detection. The constructed MOF featuring CO2-adsorbing property and exposed Lewis-acid metal sites could serve as an excellent catalyst for CO2-based chem. fixation. Catalytic activity of the MOF was confirmed by remarkably high efficiency on CO2 cycloaddn. with small epoxides. When extending the substrates to larger ones, its activity showed a sharp decrease. These observations reveal that MOF-catalyzed CO2 cycloaddn. of small substrates was carried out within the framework, while large ones cannot easily enter into the porous framework for catalytic reactions. Thus, the synthesized MOF exhibits high catalytic selectivity to different substrates on account of the confinement of the pore diam. The high efficiency and size-dependent selectivity toward small epoxides on catalytic CO2 cycloaddn. make this MOF a promising heterogeneous catalyst for carbon fixation.

Considering the rapid increase of CO2 emission, especially from power plants, there is a constant need for materials which can effectively eliminate post-combustion CO2 (the main component: CO2/N2 = 15/85). Here, we show the design and synthesis of a Cu(II) metal-organic framework (FJI-H14) with a high density of active sites, which displays unusual acid and base stability and high volumetric uptake (171 cm(3) cm(-3)) of CO2 under ambient conditions (298 K, 1 atm), making it a potential adsorbing agent for post-combustion CO2. Moreover, CO2 from simulated post-combustion flue gas can be smoothly converted into corresponding cyclic carbonates by the FJI-H14 catalyst. Such high CO2 adsorption capacity and moderate catalytic activity may result from the synergistic effect of multiple active sites.

The development of efficient and low energy-consumption catalysts for CO2 conversion is desired, yet remains a great challenge. Herein, a class of novel hollow porous carbons (HPC), featuring well dispersed dopants of nitrogen and single Zn atoms, have been fabricated, based on the templated growth of a hollow metal-org. framework precursor, followed by pyrolysis. The optimized HPC-800 achieves efficient catalytic CO2 cycloaddn. with epoxides, under light irradn., at ambient temp., by taking advantage of an ultrahigh loading of (11.3 wt %) single-atom Zn and uniform N active sites, high-efficiency photothermal conversion as well as the hierarchical pores in the carbon shell. As far as we know, this is the first report on the integration of the photothermal effect of carbon-based materials with single metal atoms for catalytic CO2 fixation.

Industrial synthesis is driven by a delicate balance of the value of the product against the cost of prodn. Catalysts are often employed to ensure product turnover is economically favorable by ensuring energy use is minimized. One method, which is gaining attention, involves cooperative catalytic systems. By inserting a flexible polymer into a metal-org. framework (MOF) host, the advantages of both components work synergistically to create a composite that efficiently fixes carbon dioxide to transform various epoxides into cyclic carbonates. The resulting material retains high yields under mild conditions with full reusability. By quant. studying the kinetic rates, the activation energy was calcd., for a phys. mixt. of the catalyst components to be about 50 % higher than that of the composite. Through the unification of two catalytically active components, a new opportunity opens up for the development of synergistic systems in multiple applications.

A review. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) have commanded significant attention in recent years on account of the applicability of these materials across several disciplines in material chem. The liberty of tuning the coordination nanospaces owing to the infinite choice of org. linkers and multivariate oxidn. states of the metal nodes bestows a distinguished advantage of designable architectures to this class of materials. A majority of the reported MOFs comprise of neutral frameworks as the net pos. charge on the metal ions is satisfied by the neg. charge of anionic ligands or the coordinated anions of the metal salt used in synthesis. Although being nontrivial, the synthesis of ionic MOFs (iMOFs) affords several distinct advantages over the routine neutral frameworks by virtue of the isolated charged species in confined nanospaces. The development and potential applications of such cationic or anionic frameworks is discussed thoroughly in this review. The design principles governing the formation of such charge-polarized MOFs were outlined through representative examples. The state-of-the-art ion exchange performances of competing materials were compared and a future perspective of such ionic-MOFs is proposed.

A review of the synthesis, structure and specifically the effect of counter-ions on the properties of ionic metal org. frameworks (ionic-MOFs) is presented, highlighting the important advances in this regard over the past decade. Most focus is on ionic porous metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) materials consisting of porous anionic or cationic frameworks and cationic or anionic guests. The structure and performance of cationic and anionic MOFs are influenced by several factors, such as org. ligands, metal ions and charge-balancing anions. These types of anionic and cationic materials have distinct advantages in comparison with neutral MOFs in the design of functional materials and their synthesis affords several distinct advantages over that for routine neutral frameworks by virtue of the isolated charged species in confined nano-spaces. The nanosized and charged pores in these ionic structures generate a strong interaction between the host and guest mols., including enhanced adsorption towards small gases and solvent mols. Ionic-MOFs can be easily modified via ion exchange and accommodate other charged guest mols., making them an ideal platform for different applications, such as functional materials. The development of synthesis methods by ion exchange and the potential applications of such cationic or anionic structures have been discussed thoroughly in this review.

The introduction of a defective zinc oxide (ZnO) to F-IRMOF-3 by the fast pptn. method becomes more advantageous than the conventional solvothermal method for the cycloaddn. reaction due to acid-base bifunctional active sites. The F-IRMOF-3 can be easily recovered and reused without any considerable loss of initial activity. The synthesis of the target compd. [4-[(2-propen-1-yloxy)methyl]-1,3-dioxolan-2-one, cyclic carbonate] was achieved by a reaction of carbon dioxide (CO2) with 2-[(2-propen-1-yloxy)methyl]oxirane (allyl glycidyl ether, epoxide).

A major goal of metal-org. framework (MOF) research is to control the structures and functions of materials in accordance with their specific applications. However, due to the flexible coordination modes between metal ions and org. linkers in MOFs, it is still challenging to rationally assemble a framework with deliberate structures and desired functional groups. Sometimes, two or more phases coexist in a one-pot reaction, making them difficult to sep. To this end, sieving and purifn. of MOF mixts. become vital for the following application. Herein, the formation of zirconium-based MOFs (Zr-MOFs) can be regulated in a wider two-dimensional scale by thermodn. using auxiliary linkers. The auxiliary linkers favor the formation of the targeted Zr-MOF by selectively binding to its coordination vacancies and therefore increasing its formation enthalpy to achieve the sieving of MOF mixt. Furthermore, the resulting mixed-linkers MOFs not only maintain porosities but also contain the installed auxiliary linkers as chem. handles to further incorporate functional groups, providing the possibility of introduction of active sites through post-modification. Finally, this synthetic strategy was applied to assemble a cooperative catalytic system in a MOF platform for CO2 cycloaddn. with epoxides. To the best of the authors' knowledge, this is the first example of sieving and functionalization of MOFs through insertion and post-modification of auxiliary linkers.

We reported herein a strategy for combining CUS-based MOF (CUS = coordinatively unsatd. metal sites) with ionic liq. (IL) functional sites to form bifunctional heterogeneous catalysts with extra high activity for CO2 fixation. Based on this strategy, two quaternary ammonium salt and quaternary phosphorus salt ionic liq. functionalized CUS-contg. MOF heterogeneous catalysts, MIL-101-N(n-Bu)3Br and MIL-101-P(n-Bu)3Br, have been prepd. for the first time by a post-synthesis modification method. Due to the synergetic role of dual functional sites including Lewis acid sites in the MOF framework and Br- ions in the IL functional sites, MIL-101-N(n-Bu)3Br and MIL-101-P(n-Bu)3Br exhibit high catalytic activity for the cycloaddn. of CO2 and epoxide under mild and co-catalyst free conditions, which significantly outperforms other benchmark MOF catalysts. Moreover, such bifunctional catalysts can be easily recovered and recycled several times without leaching and loss of activity. Our work thus paves a way for the development of IL functionalized MOFs as heterogeneous catalysts for CO2 fixation.

Integration of synergic Lewis acid sites and nucleophilic anions that can facilitate ring-opening of epoxide is a good way to develop efficient catalyst for cycloaddn. of CO2 with epoxides. Herein, we prepd. a novel metal-org. framework (MOF) catalyst (Cr-MIL-101-[BuPh3P]Br) through grafting quaternary phosphonium salt ionic liq. (IL) on Cr-MIL-101 by a facile post-synthetic approach. The introduction of phosphonium salt IL highly improves the catalytic activity and stability compared with the parent Cr-MIL-101-NH2. In the absence of any solvent and co-catalyst, Cr-MIL-101-[BuPh3P]Br showed excellent catalytic activity for the cycloaddn. reaction under moderate reaction conditions. Under optimized conditions, the yield and TOF of propylene carbonate can be achieved 97.8% and 1086.7 h-1, resp. This is because the synergetic interaction of dual functional sites including Cr3+ as Lewis acid sites in MOF and Br- as nucleophile in IL could promote the ring-opening of epoxide through the coordination of Cr3+ sites with O atom and the nucleophilic attack of Br- on the less sterically hindered β-carbon atom of epoxide, resp. Comparison with other reported ILs-functionalized Cr-MIL-101 or other kinds of MOFs catalysts reveals that Cr-MIL-101-[BuPh3P]Br has superior catalytic performance and potential. Moreover, Cr-MIL-101-[BuPh3P]Br as a heterogeneous catalyst also showed good chem. stability and reusability.

The design and synthesis of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) enclosed with multiple catalytic active sites is favorable for cooperative catalysis, but is still challenging. Herein, the authors developed a sequential postsynthetic ionization and metalation strategy to prep. bifunctional multivariate Zr-MOFs incorporating zinc porphyrin and imidazolium functionalities. Using this facile strategy, tetratopic [5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrinato]zinc(II) (ZnTCPP) ligands were successfully installed into the cationic Zr-MOF to obtain ZnTCPP⊂(Br-)Etim-UiO-66. These MTV-MOFs, including TCPP⊂Im-UiO-66, TCPP⊂(Br-)Etim-UiO-66, and ZnTCPP⊂(Br-)Etim-UiO-66, were well characterized and used in CO2 capture and conversion into cyclic carbonate from allyl glycidyl ether and CO2 under cocatalyst-free and 1 bar CO2 pressure conditions. The structural features and CO2 affinity properties of these MTV-MOFs can be tuned by introducing imidazolium groups or doping zinc sites. Addnl., ZnTCPP⊂(Br-)Etim-UiO-66 exhibited enhanced catalytic activities compared to other MTV-MOFs herein for obtaining the 3-allyloxy-1,2-propylene carbonate product, which was attributed to the cooperative effect of Zn2+ sites and Br- ions in this microporous ionic MTV-MOF. ZnTCPP⊂(Br-)Etim-UiO-66 can be recycled easily and used at least three times.

Ionic metal-org. frameworks (IMOFs) that integrate synergistic Lewis-acid sites (intrinsic metal centers of the frameworks) and nucleophilic anions (halides encapsulated within pores) are intriguing platforms for the design of fully heterogeneous catalytic systems for cycloaddn. of CO2 to epoxides. A new, facile and versatile synthetic approach has been used to fabricate triazolium-based IMOFs for the first time. The approach makes use of azide-alkyne click chem. and subsequent N-alkylation to post-synthetically create a cationic triazolium ring and introduce exchangeable counteranions at the same time. The IMOFs are efficient and recyclable heterogeneous catalysts for CO2 conversion under mild and cocatalyst-free conditions. In particular, the click-accessible triazolium ring provides a handle to incorporate further functionality. The MIL-101-tzmOH-Br catalyst, which integrates hydrogen-bonding hydroxy groups besides metal centers and bromide anions, shows superior catalytic performance under mild conditions.

In sites) and the I- ion in the IL functional sites, IL-[In2(dpa)3(1,10-phen)2] displayed a high catalytic activity for CO2-epoxide cycloaddn. reactions under mild and solvent-free conditions. Microwave pulses were employed for the first time in MOF-catalyzed CO2-epoxide cycloaddn. reactions to result in a high turnover frequency of 2000-3100 h-1. The catalyst had an excellent reusability and maintained a continuous high selectivity. Furthermore, only a small amt. of leaching was obsd. from the spent catalyst. A plausible reaction mechanism based on the synergistic effect of the dual-functional sites that catalyze the CO2-epoxide cycloaddn. reaction effectively is proposed.

Two water-stable, Zr-based metal-org. frameworks (MOF) (NU-1000, UiO-67) were prepd. at various size scales (100-2000 nm) for the adsorptive removal of glyphosate from aq. media. NU-1000 and UiO-67 have a three-dimensional structure; NU-1000 consists of triangular micropores and wide mesoporous channels (31 Å), UiO-67 has cage-like pores (octahedral [16 Å] and tetrahedral [14 Å] cages). NU-1000 is comprised of Zr6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(H2O)4(OH)4; UiO-67 contains Zr6O4(OH)4 as a secondary building unit. These units act as Lewis acid nodes and can interact with the glyphosate Lewis base phosphate group. Time to reach equil. was considerably reduced as the MOF size decreased. The smaller the particle size, the lesser the diffusion barrier for the analyte, which enhances the interaction between Lewis acidic metal nodes and the glyphosate mol. Lewis basic center. NU-1000 was had better efficiency and re-usability than UiO-67 which may be due to the NU-1000 larger pore diam. Theor. calcns. showed the glyphosate interaction energy with NU-1000 nodes was higher (-37.63 KJ/mol) than UiO-67 (-17.37 KJ/mol), which may be the reason for the NU-1000 higher efficiency.

Designing bipyridine-functionalized zirconium metal-organic frameworks as a platform for clean energy and other emerging applications
Tu, Thach N.; Nguyen, My V.; Nguyen, Ha L.; Yuliarto, Brian; Cordova, Kyle E.; Demir, Selcuk
Coordination Chemistry Reviews
(
2018
),

(
),
33-50

; ISSN:
0010-8545
.
(
Elsevier B.V.
)
Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are a class of cryst. and porous materials with modular structural features. This modularity has allowed MOFs to be designed and synthesized with adjustable pore sizes and shapes leading to ultrahigh porosity. Among the tens of thousands of known MOF structures, zirconium-based MOFs (Zr-MOFs) have attracted attention not only for their structural properties but also their superior chem. and thermal stabilities, which are crit. for a myriad of practical applications. In particular, bipyridine (BPY) functionalized Zr-MOFs have been received recognition for their interesting intrinsic properties, which arise from various post-modification pathways. The fact that post-modification is readily available for such MOFs paves the way towards anchoring specific components (functional groups, metals complexes, and nanoparticles) via the bipyridine docking centers, thus endowing this MOF platform with the capability to chem. alter and enhance the bulk material's properties. Throughout this review, an emphasis is placed on the prepn. of BPY-functionalized Zr-MOFs, their characterization, and subsequent applications, such as electrocatalytic or photocatalytic hydrogen evolution reactions, heterogeneous mol. catalysis, and gas storage for renewable energy. Furthermore, this review highlights the design and applications of materials from the viewpoint of materials design and the necessity and importance of installing complexity to achieve synergistic interactions. Finally, our perspective for future applications is introduced with the expectation of providing useful information to those interested in this specific MOF platform.

A homochiral metal-org. porous material with a carboxylic group at one end and a pyridyl group at the other forming oxo-bridged trinuclear metal carboxylate units in a three-dimensional framework was prepd., that allows enantioselective inclusion of metal complexes in its pores and catalyzes transesterification reactions in an enantioselective manner. The enantiopure chiral building block was prepd. from D-tartaric acid and 4-aminopyridine; then reaction with Zn2+ produced a homochiral open-framework solid, D-POST-1. The enantiomorphic L-POST-1 was obtained from the enantiomer of the building block and Zn2+ under the same conditions. The pyridyl groups in POST-1 can be converted to N-methylpyridinium without any changes of the network structure; the anion can be reversibly exchanged with other anions, e.g., PF6-, I3-, p-toluenesulfonate, etc. The pore size of POST-1 materials is modulated by N-alkylation and is dependent on alkyl chain length. The pyridyl groups are responsible for the catalytic activity of the oxo-bridged trinuclear metal complexes, in e.g., transesterification of 2,4-dinitrophenyl acetate (NPA) with ethanol, which produced Et acetate in 77% yield, only in the presence of POST-1. Transesterification with bulkier alcs. occurs more slowly or not at all, suggesting that catalysis occurs mainly in the POST-1 channels. The catalytic activity of D- and L-POST-1 is enantioselective as obsd. in the transesterification of NPA with 1-phenyl-2-propanol, which produces the corresponding esters with about 88% enantiomeric excess in favor of the resp. enantiomer.

Fast and enhanced anionic dye adsorption was obsd. in UiO-67-bpy-Me. Despite the decrease in surface area and pore vol., UiO-67-bpy-Me exhibited an evident increase in CO2 uptake compared to UiO-67-bpy. UiO-67-bpy-Me showed optical absorption up to ∼800 nm with a large red shift of 450 nm compared to the pristine UiO-67-bpy (∼350 nm). The extended optical absorption may lead to more efficiency in light use. A proof-of-concept demonstration showed that UiO-67-bpy-Me could more efficiently catalyze Me-orange degrdn. under UV-visible light irradn. than the pristine UiO-67-bpy. N-quaternization could serve as a facile post-synthetic modification method to tune the chem./phys. properties of free pyridyl-contg. MOFs.

Probing acid sites in solid catalysts with pyridine UV-Vis spectroscopy
Velthoen, Marjolein E. Z.; Nab, Sophie; Weckhuysen, Bert M.

Solid acids hold widespread applications in the field of heterogeneous catalysis. In this work, we present pyridine UV-Vis spectroscopy as a novel and promising tool to study the acidic properties of such solid acids. It was found that upon interaction with acid sites, the electronic properties of pyridine change significantly. Monitoring of consecutive adsorption and desorption of pyridine revealed absorption bands in the UV-Vis region characteristic for (a) pyridinium ions formed on Bronsted acid sites, (b) pyridine coordinated to Lewis acid sites, (c) pyridine hydrogen-bonded to surface hydroxyl groups, and (d) physisorbed pyridine. The classical pyridine FT-IR method probes the presence of different Bronsted and Lewis acid sites as well, but lacks sensitivity towards the differentiation between surface hydroxyl groups. In contrast, the pyridine UV-Vis spectroscopy method proves esp. useful for the identification and distinction of different surface hydroxyl groups, since the band position in the UV-Vis spectrum strongly depends on the chem. environment of the hydroxyl group. Moreover, utilizing a slow desorption procedure under N2 flow, it was possible to study the differences in acidic strength of the hydroxyl groups. This method and related measurement protocols were developed for the study of acidic properties within solid acids with different silica/alumina ratios, but are, in our opinion, more generally applicable to any solid acid.

This model allows the accurate charge correction of binding energies and the detn. of reliable and reproducible binding energies for each ionic liq. Shake-up/off phenomena are detd. for both C 1s and N 1s spectra. The electronic interaction between cations and anions is investigated for both simple ionic liqs. and an example of an ionic-liq. mixt.; the effect of the anion on the electronic environment of the cation is also explored. Throughout the study, a detailed comparison is made between [C8Py][A] and analogs including 1-octyl-1-methylpyrrolidinium- ([C8C1Pyrr][A]), and 1-octyl-3-methylimidazolium- ([C8C1Im][A]) based samples, where X is common to all ionic liqs.

Benefiting from the Bronsted and Lewis acid sites, Lewis basic sites, excellent chem. stability, and the mesoporous cages incorporated in the framework, JLU-MOF58 can be regarded as a remarkably efficient heterogeneous catalyst that exhibits excellent catalytic efficiency for CO2 conversion.

The correlation between dimensionality and active sites on deciding the catalytic performance of an MOF catalyst in CO2-epoxide cycloaddn. reactions has been studied. Seven In(III) based MOFs built from carboxylic and N-donor ligands possessing different dimensionalities and distinct coordination environments were chosen as solid acid catalysts for this study. The origin of the catalytic activity of an In3+/TBAB bifunctional system in a CO2-PO reaction was studied in detail by performing d. functional theory (DFT) calcns. at the M06/LACVP**++ level. The energy barrier of the propylene oxide ring opening in the presence of In3+/Br- is 11.5 kcal mol-1, which is significantly lower than those of un-catalyzed (55-63 kcal mol-1) and Br--catalyzed (19.5 kcal mol-1) reactions, which confirms the importance of the In3+/Br- binary catalytic system in the CO2-epoxide cycloaddn. reactions. The one-dimensional (1D) MOF with unsatd. metal centers exhibited higher catalytic activity (PO conversion: 91%, temp.: 50 °C, and time: 12 h) than the two- and three-dimensional MOFs. The roles of dimensionality and unsatd. metal centers in cycloaddn. reactions were explained on the basis of the results of activity testing and structural investigations. In addn., a plausible reaction mechanism for the catalytic activity of the 1D MOF was proposed with ref. to our structure-d. functional theory correlations.

A systematic approach has been employed to obtain a hydrolytically stable cationic metal-org. framework (MOF). The synthesized two-dimensional Ni(II)-centered cationic MOF, having its backbone built from purely neutral N-donor ligand, is found to exhibit uncommon resistance over wide pH range, particularly even under highly alk. conditions. This report presents a rare case of a porous MOF retaining structural integrity under basic conditions, and an even rarer case of a porous cationic MOF. The features of stability and porosity in this ionic MOF have been harnessed for the function of charge- and size-selective capture of small org. dye through ion-exchange process across a wide pH range.

A method for the synthesis of the title compds. [i.e., cyclic carbonates, 1,3-dioxolan-2-one derivs.] is reported here. The development of efficient heterogeneous catalysts for the cycloaddn. of CO2 to epoxides to produce five-membered cyclic carbonates under mild reaction conditions is of great importance. In this work, the coupling reaction of CO2 with propylene oxide (PO) to produce propylene carbonate (PC) catalyzed by MOF-5 (metal-org. frameworks) in the presence of quaternary ammonium salts (Me4NCl, Me4NBr, Et4NBr, Pr4NBr, Bu4NBr) was studied in different conditions. It was discovered that MOF-5 and quaternary ammonium salts had excellent synergetic effect in promoting the reaction, and the MOF-5/Bu4NBr catalytic system was the most efficient among them. The optimal temp. for the reaction was around 50 °C. The reaction could be completed in 6 h at low CO2 pressure with very high selectivity. A decrease of the yield of PC was not noticeable after MOF-5 was reused three times, indicating that the MOF-5 was stable. The MOF-5/Bu4NBr catalytic system was also very active and selective for the cycloaddn. of CO2 with other epoxides, such as glycidyl Ph ether, epichlorohydrin and styrene oxide. The mechanism for the coupling reaction is also discussed.

Developing catalysts that provide the effective activation of hydrogen and selective absorption of substrate on metal surface is crucial to simultaneously improve activity and selectivity of hydrogenation reaction. Here we present an unique in situ etching and coordination synthetic strategy for exploiting a functionalized metal-org. framework to incorporate the bimetallic platinum-nickel frames, thereby forming a frame within frame nanostructure. The as-grown metal-org. framework serves as a breath shell to enhance hydrogen enrichment and activation on platinum-nickel surface. More importantly, this framework structure with defined pores can provide the selective accessibility of mols. through its one-dimensional channels. In a mixt. contg. four olefins, the composite can selectively transport the substrates smaller than its pores to the platinum-nickel surface and catalyze their hydrogenation. This mol. sieve effect can be also applied to selectively produce imines, which are important intermediates in the reductive imination of nitroarene, by restraining further hydrogenation via cascade processes.

A new urea-contg. metal-org. framework (MOF) was synthesized to act as a heterogeneous catalyst. Ureas are known for self-recognition and aggregation behavior, resulting in loss of catalytic competency. The catalyst spatial isolation achievable in a porous MOF environment suggests a potentially general soln. The combination of a sym. urea tetracarboxylate strut, 4,4'-bipyridine, and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O under solvothermal conditions afforded a new microporous MOF (NU-601). This material is indeed an effective hydrogen-bond-donor catalyst for Friedel-Crafts reactions between pyrroles and nitroalkenes, whereas a homogeneous urea is much less competent. The higher rates of reaction of small substrates relative to larger ones with NU-601 strongly suggest that catalysis primarily occurs within the pores of this new material rather than on its exterior. To the best of knowledge, this approach is the first example of specific engineering of successful hydrogen-bonding catalysis into a MOF material.

A review. This crit. review will be of interest to the experts in porous solids (including catalysis), but also solid state chemists and physicists. It presents the state-of-the-art on hybrid porous solids, their advantages, their new routes of synthesis, the structural concepts useful for their 'design', aiming at reaching very large pores. Their dynamic properties and the possibility of predicting their structure are described. The large tunability of the pore size leads to unprecedented properties and applications. They concern adsorption of species, storage and delivery and the phys. properties of the dense phases. (323 refs.).

The Reticular Chemistry Structure Resource (RCSR) database of, and symbols for, crystal nets
O'Keeffe, Michael; Peskov, Maxim A.; Ramsden, Stuart J.; Yaghi, Omar M.
Accounts of Chemical Research
(
2008
),
41
(
12
),
1782-1789
CODEN:
ACHRE4
; ISSN:
0001-4842
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
During the past decade, interest has grown tremendously in the design and synthesis of cryst. materials constructed from mol. clusters linked by extended groups of atoms. Most notable are metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), in which polyat. inorg. metal-contg. clusters are joined by polytopic linkers. (Although these materials are sometimes referred to as coordination polymers, we prefer to differentiate them, because MOFs are based on strong linkages that yield robust frameworks.) The realization that MOFs could be designed and synthesized in a rational way from mol. building blocks led to the emergence of a discipline that we call reticular chem.MOFs can be represented as a special kind of graph called a periodic net. Such descriptions date back to the earliest crystallog. studies but have become much more common recently because thousands of new structures and hundreds of underlying nets have been reported. In the simplest cases (e.g., the structure of diamond), the atoms in the crystal become the vertices of the net, and bonds are the links (edges) that connect them. In the case of MOFs, polyat. groups act as the vertices and edges of the net.Because of the explosive growth in this area, a need has arisen for a universal system of nomenclature, classification, identification, and retrieval of these topol. structures. We have developed a system of symbols for the identification of three periodic nets of interest, and this system is now in wide use. In this Account, we explain the underlying methodol. of assigning symbols and describe the Reticular Chem. Structure Resource (RCSR), in which about 1600 such nets are collected and illustrated in a database that can be searched by symbol, name, keywords, and attributes. The resource also contains searchable data for polyhedra and layers.The database entries come from systematic enumerations or from known chem. compds. or both. In the latter case, refs. to occurrences are provided. We describe some crystallog., topol., and other attributes of nets and explain how they are reported in the database. We also describe how the database can be used as a tool for the design and structural anal. of new materials. Assocd. with each net is a natural tiling, which is a natural partition of space into space-filling tiles. The database allows export of data that can be used to analyze and illustrate such tilings.

Postsynthetic Tuning of Metal-Organic Frameworks for Targeted Applications
Islamoglu, Timur; Goswami, Subhadip; Li, Zhanyong; Howarth, Ashlee J.; Farha, Omar K.; Hupp, Joseph T.
Accounts of Chemical Research
(

ACHRE4
